Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Policial Science: Descriptive Representation and Policy Outcomes in Parliaments

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project assesses how representation affects policy outcomes. The project includes the construction of a dataset, the Database of Female Parliamentarians by Party Type, 1907-2012, permitting the analysis of policy outcomes based on identity. A central question in the literature is whether increasing the numerical representation of an identity group leads to expansions of group rights and the protection of group liberties; this project seeks answers to this question. The intellectual merit of the project is associated with its advances in the study of representation and the construction of the first cross-national, comprehensive dataset that tracks women in parliament by party. The database will facilitate answers to questions such as: Are women more likely to be promoted within a party when there are more of them? Does having more women in a party affect male and female voters' views about women's competence in office?

The research will have impacts beyond academia as well, contributing to current policy debates about what drives expansions in rights, participation in the economy, and more broadly, greater equality in society. Its conclusions have the potential to shape policy-making in countries and organizations that hope to increase representation or to improve laws protecting rights. The project's methods and conclusions are relevant for under-represented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Feminist activists and scholars of women in politics have long believed that having more women in politics should "matter" for promoting pro-female policies. The problem, of course, is that what constitutes a "pro-female" policy depends very much on the eyes of the beholder. The first aim of this project has been to clarify the meaning of women-friendly policies by drawing our attention to the ideological nature of policy preferences.

 

Put simply, a policy can be pro-woman if people advocating on behalf of women are interested in seeing that policy come to fruition. To the extent that women adhere to distinct political ideologies, policies of both conservative and progressive natures can therefore be “pro-woman”. The question of whether having women in politics matters for pro-woman policies can therefore be more aptly reframed as asking whether female representatives with particular political commitments are able to pass legislation that benefits or pleases women who are similarly politically committed.

 

In light of this simple reframing, I ask whether having more women in parliament has affected the nature of legislation protecting or promoting women’s reproductive rights. The preservation and enhancement of women's reproductive rights, including the right to affordable preventative contraception, as well as the right to safe ex-post contraception like abortion, have been central to the policy agenda of leftist feminist movements around the globe. Legal protections for abortion have increased dramatically since 1945. So too have the set of conditions under which women may reasonably seek an abortion. But these gains have not been uniformly distributed. Here, I seek to understand the causes of variation in women’s access to legal, safe, and liberal abortion.

 

I suggest that the type of electoral system and the distribution of female representatives within political parties have had a greater influence on women’s access to abortion than other factors such as political culture. Although the project is still in progress, I have found evidence that countries that use proportional representation show greater tendencies toward reproductive liberality than systems that have single member districts. More importantly, however, is the fact that abortion liberality has grown in tandem to the growth of women in leftist parties. When the strength of female representation in leftist parties is accounted for, other factors like religiosity become less important in determining reproductive rights across countries. 

 

These results are no less important because they are intuitive. Countless scholarly papers have questioned the relationship between women's descriptive representation and substantive policy outcomes but few find a link between the two. I argue that this is because the scope of what constitutes a "pro-woman" policy is too vague, and because the data used to test these questions -- such as indices of women's social or political rights, and the overall proportion of women in legislatures -- are too broad. Here I overcome these problems by studying a policy that has tremendous importance to many women's lives, and which has received longstanding support by women of a particular ideological position. Two primary contributions I make toward scholarship are in classifying the nature of women's reproductive rights in a large set of countries, and by generating data on the ideological leaning of national legislatures, and women within them, for these countries over time. The study's findings have further, broader impacts insofar as they help to justify the continuing advocacy of feminist groups for women's representation with reference to the ends that women in parliament promote.
